AOL -- You've got patents! 0 comments, 0 called-out + Comment now + Comment now "You've Got Mail"starring Meg Ryan and Tom Hanks
It is morning. I sit at my desk. I switch on my monitor. I am expecting some critical emails from overseas which should be my wake-up call for the day. I wait for the phone line to clear before I can dial out to connect because my wife was on the phone. Creeping across my screen fresh from my 256k dial-up connection , I am expecting to hear those famous words: “You’ve got mail!” I am the only man in America still on dial-up. I wait and wait. I am Tom Hanks in You’ve Got Mail .
Then I wake up.
You remember the movie You’ve Got Mail , the 1998 remake of the old Margaret Sullavan and James Stewart movie, The Shop Around the Corner , released in 1940. The remake starred Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan , with Hanks an owner of a big book store chain, and Meg Ryan, who runs a local book selling boutique called “The Shop Around the Corner.”
Priceline.com
So back in the real world I click on my iPad, and the news tells me that AOL had sold off much of its patent portfolio, and is licensing the rest, to Microsoft . When AOL was the — well, Microsoft — of Internet portals, it invested voluminously in technology patents. Of course, what it didn’t do is develop heavily in the means of transmission, and before long (maybe not too long, but eventually) a portal like AOL, which due to the magic of your home telephone allowed you to be part of the World Wide Web, was lost to the telephone and cable carriers who were already wired and investing more to bring broadband internet to our doorsteps. Companies like AOL and Walker Digital ( Priceline ) became famous think tanks for every product and method imaginable, employing computer telephony and digital access to accomplish every mean feat. And then patenting them.
What seems like a nice little cash pile for investors (exceeding one billion dollars) may well be less than meets the eye. It means that Microsoft has the right to either own or use without further payment to AOL every piece of technology which AOL has invented. Why would they do that? Well, I don’t even have the slightest insight into the depths of AOL’s patent portfolio. But big patent owners are very keen on acquiring patents or the rights to patents not only for those inventions that they see as diamonds in the rough (who knows? AOL’s portfolio may be full of these) but also and especially for defensive purposes. It all happens through the magic of cross-licensing. Company number one sues company number two for patent infringement. Company number two puts its own patents through the filter and comes up with a whole slew of patents as if that company wanted infringing. If you’re going to sue me, well, I’ll sue you back. So eventually, we enter into an entente. You can use mine and I can use yours, and at least we can keep out everyone else.
I’m going through this process right now with clients where we are analyzing their portfolio, looking for our potential vulnerabilities and then, as a matter of fact, looking at the vulnerabilities of the other guys. We are trying to calculate whether they will simply beg off on challenging too many of our client’s rights because it would open up a Texas death match (where both sides lose). Patent infringement is sometimes called the sport of kings. It’s more expensive than polo. The more weapons (patents) you can stockpile, the better you can insulate yourself or possibly keep harm under control.
Back when AOL was so well known that Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan starred in a movie playing off of their YOU’VE GOT MAIL trademark, the future of all of these so-called business method patents was bright, even though the development of these patents was pure speculation. A court decision in the early 90s paved the way for the business method patent, giving exclusive rights on methods not just in the technology field, but, quite famously or notoriously, for things like techniques for salting French fries in a fast food restaurant or creating a peanut butter and jelly sandwich (I wish I was being funny here). In the couple of decades which have passed, courts have put some limits on business method patents but have allowed a lot of them to remain powerful weapons which motivate companies like AOL and Microsoft to buy and sell. So, it would be easy to say AOL is abandoning the technology field, but given whom its competitors would seem to be, that’s a hard claim to make. Selling a patent portfolio of that size and scope to a company like Microsoft might mean that AOL gets lots of mail, from shareholders. True, you could buy a lot of minutes of dial-up time for a billion dollars. But how far will it go on this money? It’s easy to criticize, and if AOL really had no business model to exploit these patents on its own while Microsoft plainly does, then they might as well cash out. But if they end up just another site, AOL truly risks being cannibalized by the Big Boys. Intellectual property (IP) rights bring distinctive and often unique traits to what you do. I’ve been an intellectual property (IP) lawyer for more than 25 years. I advise my clients on how to use, defend and protect their IP assets, and have litigated their rights in the federal district courts, courts of appeal and the U.S. Supreme Court. I represent U.S. and foreign companies. I help clients decide on brand names, work on product marketing and protection strategies and advertising approval. I do a lot of work going after counterfeiters, especially for luxury goods companies. I also counsel on patent law and protection, and work extensively in copyright law, including with publishers, artists, and media companies. I’ve been lecturing and advising clients about IP rights on the Internet since the early 1990’s. I’ve had the privilege of taking leadership roles in professional organizations dedicated to advancing IP rights worldwide.
